Like other games in the genre you decide for each part of the day what you want to do, which increases or decreases certain statistics. 												Pretty good, lighthearted VN.  It has pretty cliche characters, but each one has a different side to them if you get to know them better.  It's nothing mindblowing, you won't find a lot of earthshaking literature here but it's entertaining and stays entertaining.There's two playable characters, one male and one female with four romance paths each for a total of eight paths.  Two of those paths are same-sex paths.  The stat system and picking your schedule is very gamey and doesn't do much except artificially close off the "good" endings if you do it wrong.  Basically you pick out a character you want to romance and only pick activities that are associated with the stats they apparently like.  There's no consequences for never raising any of the other stats except the two you need.  I guess you can care about grades too, but you can just study in the time blocks where your chosen stat activities aren't available.  The so-called bad boy I played that wanted to drop out of college was a top student, while still getting the girl and finding time between the sexual tension to front a band.It's a neat little story, but like I said it's not going to be an intellectual roller-coaster and it's not meant to be.  Roommates is a VN about light comedy, light romance and sweet character interaction.  You won't find a lot of philosophy, but you'll find some nifty references, a few laughs and enough sweet/cute scenes to give you diabetes.

Roommates it's that book you know it's not that good, but you like anyway. It's a mixed bag. A mixed bag of... actually, is more like a cake. A cake filled with good stuff and some bad stuff. You can choose between two characters, sweet and shy Anne or loud and obnoxious Max, and get through college. This means, of course, getting a boy/girlfriend. You'll also have to manage your time to study, get money and raise the correct stats you need for the ending you want.Okay, okay, now. How well does the game accomplish this little simulation of college? I'm a lazy bum and not in college, so I've no idea. But as a game it's pretty fun. The simulation sim part of it is pretty good and well balanced. Not too hard, not too easy. The characters are actually pretty good, even though first impressions might not say so. Cliche, but well handled and charming. You learn to like them and want to see more of them. There's diversity in them, from beliefs to oriental sexuations (yes). The comedy is good, the characters are fun to read, and you just want to keep moving forward to see more of these fun situations involving them. So the game is great? Should you run to buy it!? Errr... not quite? There's some stuff that will put some people off. First, the characters. I liked them all, but some of them are kind of a hit or miss. A lot of people will instantly hate Max, the male protagonist. And the characters are probably the only reason you'd want to keep playing, so not liking them is kind of a big deal. 												This is a great VN. I've only done one romance route so far but there are about ~6-9 depending on how you count things. I banked about 6 hours for one route, although naturally you will spend less time on your subsequent routes unless you want to reread everything. The writing is entertaining and well done. You can play as a male or female and both of them have distinctively different personalities. For each protagonist there are 3 opposite sex options and 1 same sex option. The music in the game is good and catchy (at least a couple of tracks I would listen to for fun outside of the game), although there were a few oddly silent parts that I wish had some music. The art is great and is anime-styled. Romance scenes get to the edge of where underwear comes off, and then is a "fade to black."I would suggest taking a peak at the guide for this game (on steam) so you get the best ending for your romance choice the first time through. It's not very spoilery. If you INSIST on not reading it, I would suggest making sure to make sure to get affection points in every scene with the character you want to romance (go back and test the options, etc) and focus on their associated stats (you can find out by clicking on the "stats" button) to the exclusion of almost everything else. To romance Anne (who I went with) you need to keep your grades up, too. MAKE SURE to get to have enough rest while preferring actions, if you dip below about 70% your stat increases diminish greatly. Skip events that don't involve your intended romance partner (if you're not sure, save and then test out the event)  so you get more rest. It's fast to replay the game because of the handy skip feature so don't worry about wasting too much time. Plus you get to save at any time, and I would recommend saving a lot, there are plenty of save slots too. Also ask on the forums if you need any help.This is another good Winter Wolves VN and I look forward even more to their future games. If you not sure or are new to VNs, get the game on sale.

												Winter Wolves won me over with an excellent RPG/visual novel mashup "Loren the Amazon Princess", so I was intrigued what other great games they might have under their belt. "Roommates" as a pure visual novel/dating sim might not have the "saving the world from Great Evil" level of urgency, and a stereotypical US college setting is as generic as it gets, but still, having a great experience with Loren, I was expecting a healhty amount of cheesy fun. And - a few issues aside - I get just that."Roommates" is distinctively casual in approach and won't intimidate you with plethora of options and it's nice to look at but it feels just too basic, even for what it's trying to be.Story itself has very little drama to it, just your average teenage stuff. As a consequence, the characters are a bit thin, as there is no real opportunity for them to develop any unique personality. The game just doesn't make you standing before any serious dilemma, but maybe that's the whole point. It's supposed fun in casual way, and at times, it is. As a bonus, you might learn what can be done with a jar of mayonnaise (and a little creativity!).The game is entirely about pursuing romance with characters, so all you have to do is make sure you made the right choices and have a stats at a minimum required level to "unlock" the desired ending. The issue is, while the 'right' choices in "Roommates" are mostly obvious, there are some make-or-break ones which are not. On my first playthrough, pursuing Rakesh, I didn't get the 'romance' ending solely because of picking a wrong Valentine's Day gift. So be careful, use a multiple save game slots, and be prepared to go back to your old save.As for the visuals, character art is good and the backdrops are nice, if nothing outstanding. Sound is serviceable, save for the title theme song which will get on your nerves soon with it's overdone jpop impersonation.As you can see, "Roommates" is a mixed bag, but the ultimate verdict has to be a positive one, because... well, it's a fun game on its own, and while it doesn't live up to Loren's greatness, you may want to give it a shot, especially if you are into visual novels/date sims.Pros:+ easy to get into,+ occasionally funny, light-hearted story,+ basic, but clean and tasteful presentation,+ diverse male & female romance options for each gender.Cons:- might require a look or two in walkthrough to complete each romance path,- aside from raising stats, there is no real sense of character development,- annoying title theme song.

												This will probably sound pretty damn stupid to a lot of those who have completed the game and happen to stumble upon this review, or those who researched the game beforehand, but... I didn't really know this game was specifically a dating sim. In fact, I got the impression this game doesn't really know what it wants to be. I'm going to recommend it because although I felt disappointed at the end, it was entertaining for the most part and is worth picking up at a discount.Okay, so onto what I mentioned. I got this game in a bundle. I only read the synopsis and I loaded it not knowing what to expect. This did not come across as a dating sim because everything seemed very platonic. I assumed it was a visual novel-esque (with some interaction) game based on building friendships. Now, I know some people aren't going to like me saying this, but the fact you can build stats with same-sex characters further led me to feel it's not a full dating sim. I absolutely welcome this but I've played a lot of these kinds of games and it's the first time I've come across this gameplay mechanic. I applaud the developers for that but I didn't expect it.Anyway, I played as Max and nothing seemed to suggest romance. Then 4/5 into the game a screen pops up saying (paraphrased), "Hey man, did you know your stats are specifically required to unlock romantic endings?!". I was thinking "Oh..." at this point, wishing the box had appeared earlier on. If I recall, stats affecting character interactions is mentioned once at the beginning and it's in part my fault for not exploring the interface more but I didn't know what was required for each character. In most dating sims, you go by instinct, but even if you screw up and don't build a certain stat (like fitness for the sporty girl) there will be one girl (e.g. childhood friend) who wil date you at the end regardless. Ironically, despite informing me of this it was impossible for me to get high enough stats to unlock a CG ending at that point, so I had sunk nearly eight hours (I don't rush through VNs so it lasted a while) into the game to end up with no achievements. I also wasted a lot of time on studying attaining full grade points which didn't seem to change anything by the end. If I knew this I'd have decreased my study time to get the special cutscenes.Now that you know not to make the same dumbass mistake I did and play this like a dating sim rather than a general VN, I hope you enjoy it should you get it.

												"Roommates" was a pretty fun little game. Simple and mundane as some of these things go (No aliens! Nobody is a pigeon!), but offering an interesting cast of characters. One unusual double-edged sword is that the game allows you to play as either a male or a female - cool! - but perhaps due to the need to write and code in all the extra combinations, either is left with a relatively spartan 3+1 choices to pursue.And pursue you don't, in my experience playing through the game twice. The game presents a week schedule which you plan ahead of time to gather skill points. Frequently intermixed are events where you can get to know the various other characters and increase your rating with them, but like many more visual-novel experiences you are given precious little opportunity to say "I really like X, I want to spend more time with him/her." Still, the cast are nice and varied and you can complete the game with a happy ending and without dying even if you romance nobody, which is more than I can say for a few VN/Dating sim games out there. You know who you are.If you do give the game a spin I recommend playing through once with your own choices and then perhaps again using a guide - in two playthroughs I was not able to unlock any of the 'romance' scenes, even though I was trying the second time. You need to be pretty perfect on the life decisions and have your stats geared heavily towards those favored by your crush in order to have enough points on the right track in time. Good luck!

												So, I suppose I'll start with the cons first. - The game lies to you, or at least obscures information. Specifically, you're never informed that you need  a toal sum of 600 points  in a characters associated stats to get their good ending, just that you need 500 to get an ending at all. The 600 thing is then mentioned when you have finished your first playthrough. - Getting said points is little more than spamming the same jobs and hobbies and hoping the RNG is in your favor. There's a slight amount of strategy, in that you need to keep your grades for one or two of the romances, and that low energy means lower stat gains, but for the most part, just spam and RNG.- As a result, the large variance of small humerous messages get quite annoying after a while, when you put it on "skip to new unread part", especially as you will have to suffer through an entirely new set each romance. - The soundtrack could use more variation, and if you aren't actually clicking your way through the scenes as fast as you can, you will end up with the latter half of each scene being in total silence, only to get surprised by the guitarriff again when the scene changes.Of course, that little thumb above this review is pointing up, so I unsurprisingly have some pro's as well: - The stories, while not all equally good, are for the most part quite romantic, and feel real. They also all feel different, which increases replayability, as the non-heterosexual characters' arcs change which the player character's personality. - Likewise, the Characters themselves are all likeable to some extent, and while a tad stereotypical, do feel like real people, and most of them have some sort of story arc even when you aren't trying to romance them. I especially applaud the descion to make both playable characters, well....characters, rather than just a blank slate to project yourself onto.Beyond that, there's not really that much to say. It's a good little section of stories, and I had fun playing it. Thank God for whomever introduced "skip read section" to Visual Novels and Dating Sims, though. It made replaying the game for a new romance far more tolerable.

												Roommates follows the wacky adventures of a college warband under one roof. You take the roll of either Max, or Anne catering their entire semester experience to what you see fit. Max takes the roll of the rocker scumbag who couldn't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about how he performs in his classes. He self indulges in psychoactive drugs to pass his down time while sleeping with his guitar. Anne is the typical bookworm nerdy type, almost never leaving her room so she can read her kawaii desu fan fiction. Upon start of the game you become indoctrinated into your first college warband in preperation for the X games. Stare into the dark abyss known as Dominc, the supreme commander of the dorm, and all around ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. His favorite past times include kicking dogs, MMO RPG's, and refusing to remove the stick in his anal cavity.Soon after you meet Isabella, the not at all sexual innuendo laced character in the whole damn game. This expertly crafted character who wears very little clothing will slowly sneak right into your heart. She barely holds down her job at the campus coffee shop, because no matter what you order you'll get ♥♥♥♥ing candy. And who could forget Sally, a devote follower to the Vegan lifestyle. Events around this character include:Discussing the benefits of eating that one cowWhy Five Guys is a gift to all human kindExperimenting on baby rabbits is for the betterment of mankindWhy am I still doing thisAnd the final boss, Rakesh. He is the right hand of darkness, and should be both feared and respected. You will be under his influence the moment you start the game. You will be convinced that every event played within the game should be catered to Rakesh. This is a noob trap. His end goals include getting you into an extremely erotic bunny suit, giving him a mayo sponge bath, and force feeding him paper. Rakesh is an evil in this game you must try to avoid at all costsThe game also includes many forgetable side characters such as Spinny Glasses guy, Roxanne the anti Anne character, kinda chubby girl who you can decide to bully if you so choose (If you do, you're kind of a♥♥♥♥♥♥, and last but not least, Chad the hunk cake. He is the secret mini boss you must face if you decide to romance Isabella, and lets face it, you're all going to.The core gameplay revolves around reading text while looking at still images in the background. The characters have a wide range of animation such as smiling, blushing, and opening and closing their mouth. If you're lucky you'll be treated with some amazing sound effects to go with the scenario. More gameplay mechanics include Lock Picking, Bunny Hopping, and an RPG inspired spreadsheet level up system. The game has three difficulties: Easy, Standard, and Nightmare. Upon extensive playtime, I have no idea what the difference between Easy and Normal is. Nightmare mode adds elements such as not being able to heal unless you drink a potion, and the only way to repair broken limbs is with a doctors bag, or visting a doctor. The one major event in this game is Vladimir's gambit. You must complete some ridiculous class project with a chosen partner. You can either actually do the work, or betray your partner so you both get a guaranteed C. Vladimir will tempt you with promises of wealth and a seat of power. This is a trick, and you must give in to unlock the bonus artwork. The game will have one of two endings at this point: You and Anne will pass Vladimir's gambit, and you'll recieve the "Not Bronze Anymore" lovers ending. The other ending has you sacrificing Anne to solidify your rise to power. Rakesh will enter at this point, stating there can be only two, a master and apprentice. This nets you the "Whose Side Are You On?" achievement right as he slides the cerimonial dagger into your chest.I would not recommend this game.

												An okay dating sim set in a nameless American college.You can play as either a bookworm girl or a budding rock-star boy; the game covers the first year of college, as these two get to know their four housemates and find romance.  The characters are all fine, and the stories are pretty good; I particularly appreciated that relationships progress at a believable pace.That being said, the time management aspect of the game feels unbalanced.  I liked having to balance studying and raising your other stats with resting.  But forcing players to make an explicit choice between resting and experiencing the plot seems like a bad decision.  Furthermore, some of the characters are effectively easier to romance than others, simply because of when you can do certain activities or take certain jobs.  That also affects the replayability of the game.  If you are playing as Max and want to romance Anne (a decision, by the way, which needs to be made in Week 1 if you have any hope of doing so successfully), you can only do jobs that raise the appropriate stats on three days each week, and there are only five time periods in which you can do leisure activities that she will appreciate.  And so, you do all of them--because you need every last one of those particular stat points you can get.  Really, then, the only interesing game play is what percentage of the time you study vs. rest--and there isn't a lot of depth there.It's not a bad game:  if you like Dating Sims (especially dating sims with non-traditional gender pairings), then you'll probably like this one.  Just don't expect greatness.

However, if you're looking for some laughs and just some feel goods, then I highly recomend it.The characters are mainly stereotypical college students. You've got the studious bookworm Anne. The rocker/troublemaker Max. The tightwad dormrep Dominic. The sexy party girl Isabela. The artist Rakesh. and the "friend of the earth" Sally. And while they are mostly stereotypes, they do have just enough depth to keep them from getting annoying. Also, one bonus for this game, is that when/if you romance some one, the rest don't disappear. All through the game you are given MANY chances to interact with your roommates. However, if you don't like one of them, you can just skip their interactions. Also, all members of Latin House are romaceable, though not all at once. For both potential main characters has four romance options(yes that includes the other potential protag.)The gameplay, while having your traditional visual novel choice making, also has some stat. management where you plan out your character's week. In this you need to balance your grades, social life, and rest(kinda like the real thing). you also need to build certain stats associated with your chosen romance option. Each has two, a primary and a secondary. Get the stats to certain levels at certain checkpoints in the game and you get the full romance. Also, one thing that isn't completely explained in the game, is that both Anne and Max have a goal that they want to acheive by the end of the year. While the game does tell you when you need to start working towards it, you need to figure out the details on your own.As for the music, if you don't like the song in the trailer, either don't buy the game or play it on mute. Cause they play the song in the game alot. And the rest of the music is along the same lines.Hope this all helped/made sense.

												9/10I only played through Anne's perspective and went after Max so keep that in mind.Game Visual Quality:Overall this game is actually a very good dating sim. Coming from past Winter Wolves games, this is a huge step up in quality. While there is still grinding in terms of getting stats up to get the special ending as per all games made by this company, the quality of this game is much higher and very polished. The UI looks better and the music sounds better as well. PremiseYou're moving into a living area and are seeking personal growth. For Anne this is trying to be more social after living a sheltered life. You have 21 weeks to get two stats up to a total of over 600 to get the good ending. ConThis is my one complaint about the game and why I won't be replaying it to get the other endings. Even on easy mode you need to have good management of what you're doing week to week. To be honest, I can see making it hard onr hard or normal mode so you actually have to try on your first playthrough. But to still have it be a large in factor in easy mode when you're just trying to see the other endings is just annoying. Though honestly, this is my only problem with the game and I might return to play through other endings one day.SolutionIn the game a very underlooked at attribute is your energy, if it falls below 70% you have more of a chance of failing at activities so it's important you keep that up. This means sleeping in and taking naps and going to bed early a lot. Also it's amusing to note that studying on your own gives you a higher booste to grades than attending class... Reminds me of actual college. So as long as you keep your energy up you should be able to exceed the 600 points required but mind you I did this on easy mode, you might just make it on normal. This does feel like it needs rebalancing to be honest to be less grindy feeling but not that much extra effort.ProsNow for the good in this game, for once in a dating sim your own character experiences growth! Anne will grow to be more social and Max can be more studious, based on your own decisions while playing as them of course. There is a decently diverse group of people to court and it's really nice that the game includes same gender relationships. It's just something that in this day and age should be more normal in a dating sim.You'll have a few events during the week that you can either skip and gain energy or play and raise relationships with other characters. Skipping is a good way to regain energy if the event doesn't relate to the character you're trying to woo. Of course at the end if you never help the other characters you won't see what happens to them at the end but hey, they're not the one you're trying to date!Pros Cont.Okay one major thing in dating sims is well the lack of taking it all the way in relationships. I mean, I'm not in it for that but still, it makes things feel more real when you sleep with the character you're dating. This game does this right. Mid game if you've wooed your chosen character enough you can sleep with them. Then through the rest of the school year they'll give you small events where it's almost said that you slept together again. The ending scenes that are final are usually character resolution ones so any conflict a character faced is solved. It's a very good way to pace the game and gives a sense of completion and a level of realness. Oh and you also get nice drawings of half naked characters but ya know... that's just uhm.. it's a nice "touch".ConclusionThe writing in this game is great and the interactions between housemates feels real. Aside from the grindyness of getting points in your skills/traits for your bae, its an amazing experience. I would highly reccomend getting this game. If they ever rebalance the point system I would totally give this game a full 10/10.
